Note that an HTML error in the new documentation may cause the display of other documentation changes to be presented incorrectly. For instance, failure to close a <code> tag will cause all subsequent paragraphs to be displayed differently.

Class CharEscapers, String decodeUri(String)

Percent-decodes a US-ASCII string into a Unicode string. UTF-8 encoding is is used to determinedetermine what characters are represented by any consecutive consecutive sequences of the form "%XX".

This replaces each occurrence of '+' with a space, ' '. So this method method should not be used forfor non application/x-www-form-urlencoded strings such such as host and path. @param uri a percent-encoded US-ASCII string @return a Unicode string

Class CharEscapers, String escapeUri(String)

Escapes the string value so it can be safely included in URIs. For details details on escaping URIs, see section 2.4 of RFC 2396.

When encoding a String, the following rules apply:

  • The alphanumeric characters "a" through "z", "A" through "Z" and "0" through "9" remain thethe same.
  • The special characters ".", "-", "*", and "_" remain the same.
  • The space character " " is converted into a plus sign "+".
  • All other characters are converted into one or more bytes using UTF-8 8 encoding and eacheach byte is then represented by the 3-character string "%XY", where "XY" is the two-digit, uppercase, hexadecimal representation of the the byte value.

      Note: Unlike other escapers, URI escapers produce uppercase uppercase hexadecimal sequences. FromFrom RFC 3986:
      "URI producers andand normalizers should use uppercase hexadecimal digits digits for all percent-encodings."

      This escaper has identical behavior to (but is potentially much faster faster than):

      • java.net.URLEncoder.encode(String, String) with the encoding encoding name "UTF-8"
Class CharEscapers, String escapeUriPath(String)

Escapes the string value so it can be safely included in URI path segments. For details onon escaping URIs, see section 2.4 of RFC 3986.

When encoding a String, the following rules apply:

  • The alphanumeric characters "a" through "z", "A" through "Z" and "0" through "9" remain thethe same.
  • The unreserved characters ".", "-", "~", and "_" remain the same.
  • The general delimiters "@" and ":" remain the same.
  • The subdelimiters "!", "$", "&", "'", "(", ")", "*", ",", ";", and and "=" remain the same.
  • The space character " " is converted into %20.
  • All other characters are converted into one or more bytes using UTF-8 8 encoding and eacheach byte is then represented by the 3-character string "%XY", where "XY" is the two-digit, uppercase, hexadecimal representation of the the byte value.

Note: Unlike other escapers, URI escapers produce uppercase uppercase hexadecimal sequences. FromFrom RFC 3986:
"URI producers andand normalizers should use uppercase hexadecimal digits digits for all percent-encodings."

Class CharEscapers, String escapeUriQuery(String)

Escapes the string value so it can be safely included in URI query string string segments. When thethe query string consists of a sequence of name=value pairs pairs separated by &, the names andand values should be individually encoded. If If you escape an entire query string in one pass withwith this escaper, then the the "=" and "&" characters used as separators will also be escaped.

This escaper is also suitable for escaping fragment identifiers.

For details on escaping URIs, see section 2.4 of RFC 3986.

When encoding a String, the following rules apply:

  • The alphanumeric characters "a" through "z", "A" through "Z" and "0" through "9" remain thethe same.
  • The unreserved characters ".", "-", "~", and "_" remain the same.
  • The general delimiters "@" and ":" remain the same.
  • The path delimiters "/" and "?" remain the same.
  • The subdelimiters "!", "$", "'", "(", ")", "*", ",", and ";", remain remain the same.
  • The space character " " is converted into %20.
  • The equals sign "=" is converted into %3D.
  • The ampersand "&" is converted into %26.
  • All other characters are converted into one or more bytes using UTF-8 8 encoding and eacheach byte is then represented by the 3-character string "%XY", where "XY" is the two-digit, uppercase, hexadecimal representation of the the byte value.

Note: Unlike other escapers, URI escapers produce uppercase uppercase hexadecimal sequences. FromFrom RFC 3986:
"URI producers andand normalizers should use uppercase hexadecimal digits digits for all percent-encodings."

Class Escaper

An object that converts literal text into a format safe for inclusion in a a particular contextcontext (such as an XML document). Typically (but not always), the the inverse process of "unescaping" thethe text is performed automatically by the the relevant parser.

For example, an XML escaper would convert the literal string {@code code "Foo"} into {@codecode "Foo<Bar>"} to prevent {@code ""} from from being confused with an XML tag. When thethe resulting XML document is parsed, the parser API will return this text as the original literalliteral string {@code code "Foo"}.

An {@code Escaper} instance is required to be stateless, and safe when used used concurrently byby multiple threads.

Several popular escapers are defined as constants in the class class CharEscapers. @since 1.0

Class Escaper, String escape(String)

Returns the escaped form of a given literal string.

Note that this method may treat input characters differently depending on on the specific escaperescaper implementation.

  • UnicodeEscaper handles UTF-16 correctly, including including surrogate character pairs. If the input is badly formed the escaper should throw IllegalArgumentException.
@param string the literal string to be escaped @return the escaped form of {@code string} @throws NullPointerException if {@code string} is null @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code string} contains badly formed formed UTF-16 or cannot be UTF-16 or cannot be escaped for any other reason
Class PercentEscaper

A {@code UnicodeEscaper} that escapes some set of Java characters using the the URI percent encodingencoding scheme. The set of safe characters (those which remain remain unescaped) can be specified onon construction.

For details on escaping URIs for use in web pages, see section 2.4 of RFC 3986.

When encoding a String, the following rules apply:

  • The alphanumeric characters "a" through "z", "A" through "Z" and "0" through "9" remain thethe same.
  • Any additionally specified safe characters remain the same.
  • If {@code plusForSpace} was specified, the space character " " is is converted into a plus signsign "+".
  • All other characters are converted into one or more bytes using UTF-8 8 encoding and each bytebyte is then represented by the 3-character string "%XY", where "XY" is the two-digit, uppercase, hexadecimal representation of the the byte value.

RFC 2396 specifies the set of unreserved characters as "-", "_", ".", "!", "~", "*", "'", "(" andand ")". It goes on to state:

Unreserved characters can be escaped without changing the semantics of the the URI, but thisthis should not be done unless the URI is being used in a context context that does not allow the unescapedunescaped character to appear.

For performance reasons the only currently supported character encoding of of this class is UTF-8.

Note: This escaper produces uppercase hexadecimal sequences. From RFC 3986:
"URI producers and normalizersnormalizers should use uppercase hexadecimal digits for for all percent-encodings." @since 1.0

Class PercentEscaper, constructor PercentEscaper(String, boolean)

Constructs a URI escaper with the specified safe characters and optional optional handling of the spacespace character. @param safeChars a non null string specifying additional safe characters characters for this escaper (the for this escaper (the ranges 0..9, a..z and A..Z are always safe and and should not be specified here) @param plusForSpace true if ASCII space should be escaped to {@code +} rather than {@code %20} @throws IllegalArgumentException if any of the parameters were invalid

Class PercentEscaper, String SAFEPATHCHARS_URLENCODER

A string of characters that do not need to be encoded when used in URI path path segments, asas specified in RFC 3986. Note that some of these characters do do need to be escaped when used inin other parts of the URI.
Class PercentEscaper, String SAFEQUERYSTRINGCHARS_URLENCODER

A string of characters that do not need to be encoded when used in URI URI query strings, asas specified in RFC 3986. Note that some of these characters characters do need to be escaped when used inin other parts of the URI.
Class UnicodeEscaper

An Escaper that converts literal text into a format safe for for inclusion in a particularparticular context (such as an XML document). Typically (but but not always), the inverse process ofof "unescaping" the text is performed performed automatically by the relevant parser.

For example, an XML escaper would convert the literal string {@code code "Foo"} into {@codecode "Foo<Bar>"} to prevent {@code ""} from from being confused with an XML tag. When thethe resulting XML document is parsed, the parser API will return this text as the original literalliteral string {@code code "Foo"}.

As there are important reasons, including potential security issues, to to handle Unicode correctlycorrectly if you are considering implementing a new escaper escaper you should favor using UnicodeEscaper whereverwherever possible.

A {@code UnicodeEscaper} instance is required to be stateless, and safe when when used concurrently byby multiple threads.

Several popular escapers are defined as constants in the class class CharEscapers. To createcreate your own escapers extend this class and and implement the .escape(int) method. @since 1.0

Class UnicodeEscaper, int codePointAt(CharSequence, int, int)

Returns the Unicode code point of the character at the given index.

Unlike Character.codePointAt(CharSequence, int) or or String.codePointAt(int) thisthis method will never fail silently when when encountering an invalid surrogate pair.

The behaviour of this method is as follows:

  1. If {@code index >= end}, IndexOutOfBoundsException is thrown.
  2. If the character at the specified index is not a surrogate, it is is returned.
  3. If the first character was a high surrogate value, then an attempt is is made to read the nextnext character.
    1. If the end of the sequence was reached, the negated value of the the trailing high surrogatesurrogate is returned.
    2. If the next character was a valid low surrogate, the code point point value of the high/lowlow surrogate pair is returned.
    3. If the next character was not a low surrogate value, then then IllegalArgumentException is thrown.
  4. If the first character was a low surrogate value, IllegalArgumentException isis thrown.
@param seq the sequence of characters from which to decode the code point @param index the index of the first character to decode @param end the index beyond the last valid character to decode @return the Unicode code point for the given index or the negated value of of the trailing high the trailing high surrogate character at the end of the sequence
Class UnicodeEscaper, String escape(String)

Returns the escaped form of a given literal string.

If you are escaping input in arbitrary successive chunks, then it is not not generally safe to useuse this method. If an input string ends with an an unmatched high surrogate character, then thisthis method will throw throw IllegalArgumentException. You should ensure your input is valid UTF-16 before calling this this method. @param string the literal string to be escaped @return the escaped form of {@code string} @throws NullPointerException if {@code string} is null @throws IllegalArgumentException if invalid surrogate characters are are encountered

Class UnicodeEscaper, char[] escape(int)

Returns the escaped form of the given Unicode code point, or {@code null} if this code pointpoint does not need to be escaped. When called as part of an an escaping operation, the given code pointpoint is guaranteed to be in the range range {@code 0 < cp < Character#MAX_CODE_POINT}.

If an empty array is returned, this effectively strips the input character character from the resultingresulting text.

If the character does not need to be escaped, this method should return return {@code null}, ratherrather than an array containing the character representation representation of the code point. This enables thethe escaping algorithm to perform more more efficiently.

If the implementation of this method cannot correctly handle a particular particular code point then itit should either throw an appropriate runtime exception or or return a suitable replacementreplacement character. It must never silently discard discard invalid input as this may constitute a security risk. @param cp the Unicode code point to escape if necessary @return the replacement characters, or {@code null} if no escaping was was needed

Class UnicodeEscaper, String escapeSlow(String, int)

Returns the escaped form of a given literal string, starting at the given given index. This method isis called by the .escape(String) method when it it discovers that escaping is required. It isis protected to allow subclasses to to override the fastpath escaping function to inline theirtheir escaping test.

This method is not reentrant and may only be invoked by the top level level .escape(String) method. @param s the literal string to be escaped @param index the index to start escaping from @return the escaped form of {@code string} @throws NullPointerException if {@code string} is null @throws IllegalArgumentException if invalid surrogate characters are are encountered

Class UnicodeEscaper, int nextEscapeIndex(CharSequence, int, int)

Scans a sub-sequence of characters from a given CharSequence, returning the index ofof the next character that requires escaping.

Note: When implementing an escaper, it is a good idea to override override this method forfor efficiency. The base class implementation determines determines successive Unicode code points and invokesinvokes .escape(int) for each of of them. If the semantics of your escaper are such that codecode points in the the supplementary range are either all escaped or all unescaped, this method method can bebe implemented more efficiently using CharSequence.charAt(int).

Note however that if your escaper does not escape characters in the the supplementary range, youyou should either continue to validate the correctness correctness of any surrogate characters encountered oror provide a clear warning to users users that your escaper does not validate its input.

See PercentEscaper for an example. @param csq a sequence of characters @param start the index of the first character to be scanned @param end the index immediately after the last character to be scanned @throws IllegalArgumentException if the scanned sub-sequence of {@code csq} contains invalid contains invalid surrogate pairs
